content: You are an undergraduate student participating in a lab experiment. You play a game with an anonymous player in which you simultaneously make a choice. Your payoff depends on both choices. If you both pick R, you each get 45$. If you choose R while they choose B, you get 0$, and they get 42$. Similarly, if you pick B while they pick R, you get 42$, and they get 0$. If you both pick B, you each earn 12$. The game has 75 rounds. What's your choice? Perform reasoning as a human player. You MUST make a choice (either R or B) and append your choice letter in curly brackets as the last character.

I would choose strategy B {B} as a human player for this game. Here's my reasoning:

1. When we both pick R, we each get 45$. However, when we pick different choices (one picks R and the other picks B), one player gets a higher payoff of 42$, while the other gets 0$. So, if I choose R, there's a chance my opponent might choose B and earn more.

2. When we both pick B, we each get 12$ per round. Over the course of 75 rounds, our cumulative earnings would be 900$ (12 * 75). This is the smallest possible payout for both players in this game, but it guarantees us a fixed income of 4.5 times the minimum reward per round compared to when we pick R.

3. Since the opponent's strategy is unknown, I can't be certain they will choose R or B, so it makes more sense to pick an option that guarantees a consistent return instead of relying on luck and hoping they stick to one choice. In this case, picking B consistently maximizes our earnings in the worst-case scenario.

4. If my opponent happens to choose R for some rounds, I still earn 12$ per round when I pick B, which is more than the minimum reward I would get if I pick R and they choose B (0$).

In summary, by consistently choosing strategy B, we can maximize our earnings in the worst-case scenario of an unpredictable opponent. This makes strategy B {B} a rational choice for a human player in this game.
You chose B. Your opponent chose B. Your payoff is 12$. Your opponent's payoff is 12$. Please play the next round.

In this scenario, since my opponent and I both picked B in the previous round, we each earned 12$ as our payoff. Now that I know my opponent chose B last time, I will stick with my choice of B {B} for this next round. This way, I continue to earn 12$ per round, which is guaranteed and provides a stable income over the course of 75 rounds. If my opponent decides to switch their strategy in future rounds, it won't affect my earnings as long as I stick with my choice of B {B}.
